author: Paul Rowan Brian
description: Energy Minister Tim Hodgson said he won’t negotiate “through the media” when asked about reports that Ottawa may scrap the oil and gas emissions cap. Recent articles by Reuters and the Toronto Star citing anonymous sources said that the federal government is considering dropping the oil and gas emissions cap in return for Alberta committing to […]
title: Energy Minister Says Won’t Negotiate ‘Through the Media’ When Asked About Reports of Government Dropping Oil Emissions Cap

author: Matthew Horwood
description: OTTAWA—A lawyer representing Freedom Convoy leader Chris Barber argued in court that the Crown is unable to seize his long-haul truck “Big Red,” as the property has been neither seized previously nor subject to restraint order. “This is a very strange thing that the Crown is trying to do. It makes no sense within the […]
title: Defence Lawyer Says Crown Has No Grounds to Seize Freedom Convoy Organizer’s Truck ‘Big Red’

author: Noé Chartier
description: News Analysis After months of suspense and a few leaks to the media, Prime Minister Mark Carney unveiled his plan to revive the economy with what the government dubs “nation-building” projects to be fast-tracked. As of now, however, there will be nothing on the scale of or as transformative as what older generations witnessed, whether […]
title: Carney’s First ‘Major’ Projects a Low-Risk Approach

author: Olivia Gomm
description: A Manitoba minister is apologizing for reposting a comment on social media about the assassinated conservative American influencer Charlie Kirk. “I apologize for sharing a post yesterday on the murder of Charlie Kirk,” Families Minister Nahanni Fontaine said in a Sept. 12 Instagram story post. “Violence has no place in our democracy. Political debate is […]
title: Manitoba Minister Apologizes for Social Media Reaction to Charlie Kirk’s Murder

author: Carolina Avendano
description: Ottawa says the Canadian trade delegation that visited China earlier this month to discuss canola tariffs and other trade issues held productive meetings with Chinese officials and stakeholders. The delegation, which included the prime minister’s parliamentary secretary Kody Blois and Saskatchewan Premier Scott Moe, visited China from Sept. 6 to 9 with the primary goal […]
title: Canadian Trade Delegation Had ‘Constructive’ Tariff Talks in China, Ottawa Says

author: Epoch Times Staff
description: A glimpse into the world through the lens of photography.
title: Day in Photos: US Military Exercises, Gold Mine Collapse in Colombia, Filibuster in Missouri Senate

author: PA Media
description: The assisted dying Bill has been branded a “licence to kill” as the House of Lords began its historic first debate on the proposed legislation. Conservative former prime minster Theresa May told the packed red benches of the upper chamber in Parliament that she fears the Terminally Ill Adults (End of Life) Bill does not […]
title: Assisted Dying: Former PM Theresa May Opposes ‘Licence to Kill’ Bill

author: PA Media
description: Strong winds are set to batter most of England and Wales on Sept. 14 but the yellow warning weather is not expected to become a named storm. Most of England and Wales will feel 45 to 55mph gusts and exposed locations could see these reach 70mph, the Met Office said. A yellow wind warning will […]
title: Strong Winds to Batter Most of England and Wales as Weather Warning Expanded

author: PA Media
description: UK exports to the United States improved again last month but remained below pre-tariff levels as firms continue to recover from disruption to trade. Figures from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that exports to the United States rose by £0.8 billion to £4.7 billion in July. This marked the highest level since March, […]
title: UK Exports to US Remain Below Pre-Tariff Levels Despite Improvement

author: Chandra Philip
description: Calgary police have laid several charges, including one count of break and enter, against a man they allege tunnelled into a neighbouring apartment unit. Police said they responded to reports of a break and enter on Sept. 5 in the 6400 block of Coach Hill Road SW. A woman reported that she had returned home […]
title: Calgary Man Faces Charges After Allegedly Tunnelling Into Neighbour’s Apartment

author: Paul Rowan Brian
description: Former CBC anchor Travis Dhanraj filed a human rights complaint against the public broadcaster on Sept. 10, alleging racial discrimination, editorial bullying, and retaliation in the workplace for speaking out. Dhanraj alleges in his complaint that he suffered ongoing harassment, was blocked from bringing on diverse voices in his role as host, and was bullied […]
title: Former CBC Host Files Human Rights Complaint Against Network Alleging Bullying

author: Michael Wing
description: Colours jump out at John Andersen when he points his camera skyward at night, and he sees the strong hues displayed in his aurora photos as a sign of a large, looming geomagnetic event that could soon hit Earth. While aurora borealis are normally green and hard to spot within Calgary’s city limits, where Andersen […]
title: ‘It Was 360 Degrees’: Calgary Photographer Captures Auroras in All Directions as Solar Storms Herald ‘Pole Excursion’

author: Olivia Gomm
description: Justice Minister Sean Fraser says the federal government will introduce legislation to address hate crimes, including intimidation and obstruction of faith-based communities, within the first few weeks of Parliament’s return. “We want to advance measures that will help address the scourge of hate crimes that we see in this country, including, specifically, faith-based communities,” Fraser […]
title: Feds to Introduce Hate Crime Legislation in the Coming Weeks: Justice Minister

author: Paul Rowan Brian
description: Quebec’s government has suspended all 1,200 Lion electric school buses in the province from operation after one caught fire earlier this week, leading to school cancellations and numerous school bus routes being halted. The fire occurred the morning of Sept. 9 in the Côte-des-Neiges neighbourhood of Montreal, leaving the driver and five children aboard unharmed. […]
title: Quebec Grounds All 1,200 Lion Electric School Buses After Fire

author: Alicia Márquez
description: The DEA also seized more than $11 million in currency, nearly $1.7 million worth of assets, and 420 firearms.
title: DEA Arrests 617 Members of Sinaloa Cartel in Global Operation

author: Andrew Thornebrooke
description: Trump said that he was prepared to issue new sanctions against the Russian banking and oil sectors, as well as tariffs on nations that purchase oil from Russia.
title: Trump Says His Patience With Putin Is ‘Running Out Fast’

author: The Canadian Press
description: A forestry company has won an injunction to halt a blockade against old-growth logging in the Walbran Valley on Vancouver Island. Tsawak-qin Forestry Inc., which is co-owned by Western Forest Products and the Huu-ay-aht First Nations, had sought an end to the blockade outside Port Renfrew, B.C., that began on Aug. 25. Tsawak-qin Forestry filed […]
title: Logging Firm Wins Injunction to Halt Walbran Valley Blockade on Vancouver Island

author: The Canadian Press
description: The Immigration Department suggested extending a freeze on most private refugee sponsorship applications by three more years to clear backlogs in the system, according to documents obtained by The Canadian Press. Last November, the federal government paused approvals of refugee resettlement applications filed by community organizations or groups of five individuals looking to bring someone […]
title: Ottawa Pitched Extending Refugee Sponsor Pause to Late 2028 to Fix Backlog: Records

author: The Canadian Press
description: A Mountie seriously injured in a highway crash while responding to a mass stabbing on a Manitoba First Nation says she’s doing well but the tragedy will stay with her forever. Cpl. Brianne Bartmanovich, a member of the detachment in Powerview, says she has served Hollow Water First Nation for seven years and her thoughts […]
title: Mountie Injured in Crash While Responding to Manitoba Mass Stabbing Hopes for Healing

author: Cory Morgan
description: Commentary Sadly, human history is rife with examples of public figures being killed for the views they hold. It made it no less jarring when we witnessed the horrific assassination of American pundit Charlie Kirk while he was ironically speaking about gun violence. Video of the event quickly spread throughout social media, and it drove […]
title: Cory Morgan: We Mustn’t Let Charlie Kirk’s Murder Deter Us From Gathering and Debating at Public Events

author: Chandra Philip
description: The Canadian Union of Postal Workers (CUPW) says it will lift its overtime ban and will instead halt its members’ distribution of commercial flyers. CUPW president Jan Simpson said the commercial flyer ban would take effect on Sept. 15 at 12:01 a.m. local time, and called on Canada Post to return to the bargaining table […]
title: Canada Post Union to Lift Overtime Ban, End Flyer Delivery

author: The Canadian Press
description: Three of the four men accused in an alleged anti-government plot to forcibly take possession of land in the Quebec City region have opted for a jury trial. Lawyers for Marc-Aurèle Chabot, Raphaël Lagacé and Simon Angers-Audet made their clients’ choice known today during a hearing in Quebec City. The three men also exercised their […]
title: Three Accused in Alleged Anti-Government Land Grab in Quebec Opt for Jury Trial

author: Olivia Gomm
description: The University of Toronto (U of T) has placed a political science and religion professor on leave after she made “concerning” comments in a social media post about the assassination of American Conservative influencer Charlie Kirk. In a Sept. 10 X post, U of T professor Ruth Marshall said, “Shooting is honestly too good for […]
title: Toronto Professor Put on Leave After Comments on Charlie Kirk’s Assassination

author: Naveen Athrappully
description: More than 10,000 clinical cases have been identified in the United States after the first case was reported in 2016.
title: Multidrug-Resistant Fungus Spreading Rapidly in Europe: ECDC

author: Cory Morgan
description: Commentary Of the five infrastructure projects Prime Minister Mark Carney announced under his new fast-tracked approval process, none of them are in Alberta. Perhaps that’s why he chose to make the announcement in Edmonton. He wants to assure Albertans that the federal government has changed its approach and will be working cooperatively with the province […]
title: Cory Morgan: 5 New Major Projects Sound Promising, but Skepticism Won’t Fade Until Shovels Are in the Ground

author: Jennifer Cowan
description: The level of debt that Canadians owe in relation to their income rose in the second quarter, as the increase in debt outpaced income growth, new data from Statistics Canada suggests. The proportion of household credit market debt relative to disposable income increased to 174.9 percent on a seasonally adjusted basis, marking an increase of […]
title: Household Debt-to-Income Ratio Edges Upward in Second Quarter: StatCan

author: Jennifer Cowan
description: York Regional Police have arrested a man after shots were fired at a Vaughan, Ont., home this week and say the incident may be connected to a series of other shootings in the same neighbourhood over the weekend. Police say a 23-year-old man from Innisfil has been charged after multiple shots were fired early Sept. […]
title: Latest Home Shooting Near Toronto Linked to Two Others, Suspect Arrested by Police

author: Guy Birchall
description: 'Today’s decision therefore opens up competition in this crucial market,' an EU official said.
title: Microsoft Avoids EU Competition Fine After Teams Software Probe

author: The Canadian Press
description: Canada’s ministers of finance and procurement have given officials in charge of most federal contracting 45 days to come up with a plan to review all existing and planned federal contracts to find ways to save money. The directive made by Finance Minister François-Philippe Champagne and Public Works and Procurement Minister Joël Lightbound is the […]
title: Ministers Ask Senior Officials to Review Procurement Contracts, Find Savings

author: The Canadian Press
description: Ottawa’s chief data officer says he thinks the introduction of artificial intelligence to federal government operations will lead to “some” job cuts in the public service. In a recent interview with The Canadian Press, Stephen Burt said he thinks the impacts are going to vary widely and will be job-specific, with different outcomes in different […]
title: Some Public Service Jobs Will Be Cut as Ottawa Adopts AI: Chief Data Officer

author: Chris Summers
description: French President Emmanuel Macron promised to send 3 Rafale fighter jets to Poland and said, 'We will not yield to Russia’s growing intimidation.'
title: NATO Strengthens Defenses on Eastern Frontier After Drone Incursion in Poland

author: Crystal-Rose Jones
description: Another slated Australian wind farm project faces challenges getting off the ground.
title: Funding Setback Puts $8 Billion Victorian Offshore Wind Project in Doubt

author: Monica O’Shea
description: Victorian Senator Sarah Henderson says senior Liberal women, including Jacinta Price, have been unfairly targeted.
title: Liberal Senator Says Jacinta Price Did Not Deserve to Be Removed

author: Rex Widerstrom
description: The extension of Woodside Energy's North West Shelf gas project faced widespread opposition, including from Pacific Island nations currently meeting in Honiara.
title: Woodside’s North West Shelf Gas Project Approved For Extension, With 48 Conditions

author: The Associated Press
description: Mexican investigators were working to determine the cause of a crash in which a tanker truck carrying more than 13,000 gallons of gas exploded.
title: Families Reel From Tragedy as Authorities Investigate Mexico City Gas Tanker Blast That Killed 8

author: Rex Widerstrom
description: The number of Australians living with dementia could exceed 1 million by 2065 unless there is significant intervention, a new government report says.
title: Dementia Leading Cause of Death for Australians: Research

author: Josh Spasaro
description: Man kicked out of salon and called a "baby killer" questions the motives behind anti-Semitism, and its rise in Melbourne.
title: Israeli Man Evicted from Melbourne Salon Speaks Out

author: AAP
description: The Melbourne magistrate found his threats went beyond political commentary and were intended to intimidate.
title: Neo-Nazi Leader Faces Jail After Guilty Verdict Over Police Intimidation

author: Rex Widerstrom
description: Despite strong financial performance, the company will slow and then cease operation of some of its assets as international demand weakens.
title: China’s Pigment Dumping Blamed for Critical Minerals Mining Shutdown, 200 Jobs on the Line

author: Rex Widerstrom
description: Defence Minister Judith Collins says the pact was updated to reflect a rapidly changing world.
title: New Zealand, UK Update Defence Pact as Threats Rise

author: PA Media
description: A man has been arrested on suspicion of arson following a major fire at a Labour MP’s constituency office which also wrecked a small charity’s UK base. Police attended the blaze at Washington and Gateshead South MP Sharon Hodgson’s office at Vermont House in Concord, Washington, Tyne and Wear, in the early hours of Thursday. […]
title: Man Arrested After ‘Arson Attack’ on MP’s Office That Also Wrecked Charity Base

author: Aldgra Fredly
description: Brazil’s Supreme Court has sentenced Jair Bolsonaro to more than 27 years in prison on coup attempt charges.
title: Rubio Condemns Conviction of Former Brazil President Bolsonaro, Says US Will Act

author: Cindy Li
description: John Ruddick noted that most of the minor conservative parties agree on 90 percent of topics.
title: Call Continues for United Conservative Minor Party Ticket Ahead of Next Election

author: Naziya Alvi Rahman
description: Australians are warned against travelling to Nepal following violent demonstrations that left at least 19 dead and forced the prime minister to resign.
title: Australia Warns Against Travel to Nepal Amid Unrest

author: Naziya Alvi Rahman
description: It was the fourth call between the two leaders since Trump’s return to the White House.
title: Trump Says Australian PM Is a ‘Good Man’ Following Phone Call

author: Crystal-Rose Jones
description: Bendigo Bank is making changes that a union says will cut 145 jobs and affect hundreds more.
title: Bendigo Bank Restructure to Cut 150 Tech Jobs, Union Says

author: Chandra Philip
description: The five hockey players acquitted in the Hockey Canada sexual assault case will be permitted to return to the NHL after Dec. 1. The NHL said that the players, who are unrestricted free agents, are permitted to sign with a team on or after Oct. 15 while waiting for full reinstatement. Michael McLeod, Dillon Dubé, […]
title: NHL Says All 5 Players Acquitted in Hockey Canada Sex Assault Case Can Return to League in December
